job_title: Program Manager in New York, NY
pros: The work is rewarding. The programs management team is made up of subject matter experts. You will hone your writing skills in this position. The work is interesting and varied: conference planning, report writing, problem solving, support services, and monitoring. You will always be busy. The affiliate network does great work. The staff is generally friendly. There are networking opportunities. This is a great job if you like to travel for several days every six weeks. The benefits are pretty good, and you get the Jewish holidays off. Management pushes you to leave the office on time. The agency does good work. US Programs is fiscally responsible. The organization values longevity to a fault. There is a diverse staff.
cons: The organization lacks a strategic plan. The pay is lower than other national resettlement agencies. Management does not provide training and discourages the pursuit of training opportunities. There is no room for growth. There is poor communication within and between departments. The workload is sometimes unreasonable.

job_title: Program Officer in New York, NY
pros: Amazing team, learning opportunities, meaningful work, open communication, the org is fantastic
cons: Can be really overworked, not clear promotion opportunities

review_title: Avoid at all costs unless you are a refugee needing services
pros: The organization has an extremely long history of genuinely helping refugees in the US and abroad. Many of the field staff are smart, capable, and committed.  There is a strong level of technical expertise throughout the organization on the legal side (i.e. the organization is practically run by lawyers at the top).
cons: There are a shocking lack of basic elements necessary for any professional NGO, for example, as of 2018, the organization did not have a history of conducting performance reviews.  There is a mix of really wonderful people along with a toxic batch of extremely unprofessional people who because of who they are in the organization are allowed to behave in ways that would not be tolerated at a more professional NGO. Bullying is absolutely permitted, as is favoritism. Internal politics are everything at HIAS if you want to get ahead or even just keep your job. For instance, there are individuals who have been put in leadership positions who lack the basic qualifications for their jobs. HIAS is extraordinary for the kinds of risks they take on hiring shady individuals into leadership positions, while the shrinking funding possibilities under the current President are creating outright desperation among employees and HIAS' constituents.

pros: Good experience for an undergraduate does not fit someone who has more qualifications.
cons: Very little pay for a fulltime job.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: This industry is humbling. I was thrilled to reconnect with my personal roots and discover things I didn't know about history and geography! This work is meaningful and impacts the well being of others... There are some incredibly dedicated and brilliant employees who work at HIAS as well.
cons: Negative atmosphere, no accountability and the work we are capable of, never seems to be enough once you learn about the realities these people face. There's little room for career growth and SOME colleagues will not support promotions making for an awkward work atmosphere...
